repnme.cdata!:
India - Maharashtra Emergency Earthquake
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is highly satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial, Bank
            performance is satisfactory, and Borrower performance is
            highly satisfactory. Among the lessons suggested by the
            project experience are the following: 1) Careful poverty
            targeting and sensitive project design can lead to major
            poverty reduction impacts even under difficult post-disaster
            circumstances. 2) Relocation of villages that consists
            mostly of one and two story buildings during post-earthquake
            reconstruction is usually a mistake in the long-term. 3)
            Simplicity of message is essential to the adoption of
            disaster-resistant technologies. 4) Grievance procedures
            need to be in place from the outset. 5) Damage Assessments
            need criteria that are carefully tailored to each widely
            used construction type, and that lead to damage awards
            closely tied to the actual cost of what needs to be done. 6)
            Owner-driven construction was more effective in providing
            culturally and environmentally appropriate housing given the
            limited range o f options contractors were able to provide
            for the same cost.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Maharashtra Emergency Earthquake
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as highly
            satisfactory with project sustainability rated as likely.
            Both World Bank and Borrower performances were assessed as
            satisfactory to highly satisfactory. These are some of the
            key lessons learned: Bank assistance for emergency recovery
            and restoration projects should include long-term hazard
            mitigation planning and loss reduction measures as the
            primary development objective. While circumstances may call
            for some grant assistance for rehabilitation in the
            aftermath of natural disasters, the amount of grant should
            be limited so that beneficiaries contribute their own
            savings and time for rehabilitation, thereby reducing
            dependence on the state. Damage assessment criteria should
            be apt for local conditions, include fewer categories, be
            technically specific, widely publicized, and pared to fewer
            interpretations. Potential beneficiaries must have
            "ownership" of the project. Partnerships should be
            fostered with government, beneficiaries, community-based
            women's organizations and non-governmental
            organizations to ensure sustainable development. There is a
            need to address the capacity of local governments and its
            impact on sustainability as well as to take a long-term
            approach to maintenance and maintenance funding. Project
            design for emergency projects should allow for a longer
            project period than the typical three years for developing
            and implementing disaster management systems.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Maharashtra Emergency Earthquake
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project are:  (1)
            to assist with rehabilitation and reconstruction in the
            earthquake-affected state of Maharashtra in India through
            the restoration of assets and basic services; (2) to
            increase the earthquake resistance of buildings and
            infrastructure through the development of improved standards
            for design and construction; and (3) to develop the ability
            of the Government of Maharashtra to respond more effectively
            to natural disasters, including earthquakes.  The project
            consists of a detailed rehabilitation and reconstruction
            program which includes:  (a) the reconstruction of villages
            and associated infrastructure; (b) the repair,
            reconstruction and strengthening of public buildings and
            infrastructure and the improvement of transit shelters,
            including flooring, drainage and sanitation; (c) social
            rehabilitation with a particular emphasis on the needs of
            women and children; (d) economic rehabilitation (for the
            replacement of business losses); (e) community
            rehabilitation (the cost of works and materials to
            re-establish essential services); and (f) a program of
            technical assistance for the design, supervision and
            monitoring of project components, other consultancy services
            and equipment, including the development of a disaster
            management program for the State of Maharashtra, and a
            seismic monitoring and research program for the Government
            of India.
